descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Nazi Germany's genocide of European Jewry depended on far more than just members of the National Socialist Party and the country's military. From Vichy France in the West to the occupied Soviet territories in the East, the persecution, expropriation, and murder of millions involved countless civilians and state officials at all levels of government. Many of those who collaborated with the Nazis did so for personal or partisan gain and/or because they were themselves antisemites. Many others, however, were drawn into the process of genocide without necessarily having planned to aid the Germans. This course considers the causes, consequences and limits of complicity in the Holocaust. In particular, we will examine collaboration at the face-to-face level of relations between neighbors and with local officials. We will explore the most vexed questions of complicity among occupied peoples and within ghettos and concentration camps. We will follow these questions up through the end of the war and beyond and explore the measures postwar European states took (or, more commonly, did not take) to identify and punish those who profited from the murder of the continent's Jews.
